“Of course people are going to look in a different way for this season, especially at the coach. But it’s something more in the core of our club [that requires addressing].

“We need to change a lot of things and need to be consistent. Europa League will not change our problems – it’s going to give us Champions League next year, more money to spend, but the problems are still there.

“We have to change the minds of our fans with consistency, good decisions, good recruitment, good academy. This is what we need to change to take our club back to the top. This [winning the Europa League] is more of a shortcut to go to the European Cup games. Nothing more. The problems we need to solve in a different way with more time and we’re really clear on that.”

headline: Football news: Luis Diaz confirms next move as Premier League rivals have bid rejected
body: It's set to be a hectic end to the 2024/25 season. Liverpool have already claimed the Premier League title but other English clubs could be flaunting silverware very soon.

Manchester United and Tottenham go head-to-head in the Europa League final later this month in what is effectively a Champions League playoff. And with that, the pair are expected to considerably boost their summer transfer warchests.

That's when silly season really can start. In fact, a number of stars have already been linked with moves over the coming months, with rumours already starting to fly around. With that being said, take a look at the latest rumours from the Premier League and beyond:

Luis Diaz has hinted that he could sign a new contract at Liverpool despite growing reports of a potential exit. The Colombian has been strongly linked with moves to Barcelona or Saudi Arabia in the past, but in a huge boost for Arne Slot, Diaz appears to be content at Anfield.
“Since the first day I arrived, I’ve always been happy, calm, enjoying the football played at this great team,” he told Colombian news outlet Telemundo Deportes.

“We’ll be talking about it [about renewing], we’ll talk about it. For me, I’d stay however many years it takes. It also depends on the club, everything. These are details that are worked out separately. But I’m very calm, happy and enjoying the Premier League.”

Arsenal have seen a bid for Chelsea wonderkid Freddy Bernal rejected it has been claimed. It's reported that the Gunners have offered around £1.25million for the young goalkeeper, who has yet to make his senior debut.

But the Blues are determined to keep him around at Stamford Bridge for the immediate future. Bernal has played five times in the Under-18 Premier League this season, including starts in the last two matches, He was also named in the England Under-18 squad for a trio of March internationals, though he remained on the bench against the Czech Republic, France and Portugal.
Amid their interest in Bernal, Arsenal already have two talented young goalkeepers in their squad, having signed Lucas Nygaard and Tommy Setford from Nordsjaelland and Ajax respectively.

Manchester United have made Bournemouth forward Antoine Semenyo one of their priorities in the summer transfer window, instead of Bryan Mbeumo. The Red Devils are keen to add a new forward to their squad after what has been a wretched campaign.

"So, of course, if the right price - and that's going to be expensive - is coming, then I'm sure the club will be open for it. But I'm very happy he's here, and I'm convinced that Bryan will still be happy playing football here."

headline: Ruben Amorim gets major transfer boost as club drop hint over £40m Man Utd target
body: Crystal Palace are lining up a move for Strasbourg striker Emanuel Emegha as they prepare for the potential of Jean-Philippe Mateta being sold this summer. The Eagles forward has been linked with a transfer to Manchester United, amid the struggles of the Red Devils' failing forward line.

Dutch forward Emegha has scored 14 goals and provided three assists this season as Strasbourg challenge for a plac in Europe. They sit sixth in Ligue 1 but level on points with Nice in fourth under the guidance of Liam Rosenior.

The 22-year-old has already seen interest arrive from Chelsea, whose BlueCo owners also control the French team. But that does not appear to have peturbed the Eagles as they make their preparations, with Strasbourg eyeing £30million for their star.

Palace are reported to be willing to spend big if they find themselves in the position of needing to replace their star forward. Mateta has two years remaining on his current contract and could be tempted to depart if Champions League football is on offer.

Manchester United are among the chief contenders for his signature and can qualify for Europe's premier competition with victory in the Europa League final. The Frenchman will not come cheap if hee is to exit Selhurst Park.

The Red Devils have been told it will cost them £40m to sign Mateta. The Reds have already opened talks about taking the 27-year-old to Old Trafford in the summer and Palace will demand full value for their forward.

United's financial position means the club may have to generate cash from player sales if they hope to add significantly to Ruben Amorim's squad. And only four members of their squad may be spared uncertainty.

United are said to be willing to sell 'most members' of the current squad. As a result, only captain Bruno Fernandes, defender Harry Maguire, young attacker Amad and January signing Patrick Dorgu are 'immune' from the fire sale.
That means, if the price is right, Kobbie Mainoo, Luke Shaw, Manuel Ugarte, Casemiro, Rasmus Hojlund, Matthijs de Ligt, Joshua Zirkzee could all be sold in this summer's window.

Amorim has already called on the club to be brave in the summer after admitting his embarrassment. "How a manager of Manchester United is supposed to feel in that position: embarrassed and it's hard to accept.
"Everybody has to think seriously about a lot of things here. We need to be really strong in the summer and be brave.
"We are losing the feeling of we are a massive club and it's the end of the world to lose a game at home. I think that is the biggest concern in our club."

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Target close to summer move as Premier League star jumps queue
body: Manchester United's dismal league form continued on Sunday, but all eyes have already turned to Europe. A 2-0 defeat to West Ham at Old Trafford made it seven winless games on the spin, but a Europa League final win would be some consolation.

United sit 16th after dropping behind Sunday's opponents, but can still secure Champions League qualification of they beat Tottenham in Bilbao. Ange Postecoglou's Spurs are in a similar spot, also losing on Sunday to sit a point and a place behind the Red Devils.
Ruben Amorim was brutally honest after the latest defeat. "The final is not the biggest thing in our football club. We need to change a lot of things," he told Match of the Day.

"If we don't change the way we play and perform and feel this urgency of winning every game, we should not play in the Champions League. We should just stay in the Premier League and learn how to be competitive one week at a time."

A seat at Europe's top table would make United a far more appealing proposition to any potential new arrival. Matheus Cunha and Liam Delap are among the others expected to have interest from teams in the Champions League regardless of whether United get there.

"So, of course, if the right price - and that's going to be expensive - is coming, then I'm sure the club will be open for it. But I'm very happy he's here, and I'm convinced that Bryan will still be happy playing football here."

Jonathan David has long been linked with Manchester United, and is set to be available for free this summer when his Lille contract expires. However, with that date drawing ever closer, Napoli appear to have stolen a march.

According to reports on the continent, Napoli are in advanced talks over the Canadian international. There are still thought to be some elements to take care of, though, with the deal far from a sure thing.

David, 25, has scored 109 times in 231 Lille games since joining the French club in 2020. He has 25 this season, including Champions League strikes against the likes of Real Madrid, Juventus and Liverpool.
Borussia Dortmund have joined the race for Jobe Bellingham, according to talkSPORT. The same publication notes that United have scouted the teenager, currently at Sunderland.

Bellingham's elder brother Jude spent time at Dortmund before joining current club Real Madrid, and the younger sibling could make the same move to Germany. He has been a regular with Sunderland this season as Regis Le Bris' side chase promotion to the Premier League.

Sunderland finished fourth in the Championship, setting up a play-off semi-final against Coventry City. The Black Cats won the first leg away from home and will welcome Frank Lampard's side to the Stadium of Light on Tuesday.

headline: Jose Mourinho tipped for shock Man Utd return after Ruben Amorim sack hint
body: Jose Mourinho is the shock favourite to become the next Manchester United manager if they choose to axe Ruben Amorim. The Red Devils have endured a horror run under the ex-Sporting Lisbon boss - who has questioned whether he's the man for the job.

Mourinho led the Manchester outfit for just over two years before being shown the door in December 2018, but with Sir Jim Ratcliffe now calling the shots a return to Old Trafford is being talked up by the bookies - who have made Mourinho a staggering 4-1 favourite to become United’s manager for the second time.

Amorim only succeeded Erik ten Hag in November but has unable to turn around United’s fortunes in the Premier League - his side sit 16th. The Special One, who is currently in charge at Fenerbahce but is tipped to leave this summer, led United to sixth and second in his two years in charge. He also claimed the Europa League and the Carabao Cup during his debut season.

Amorim could yet deliver the Europa League himself with the final to come in Bilbao in just over a week. Victory would secure Champions League football, but that will not cover for a horrific domestic season.
The 40-year-old has confessed that he was responsible - not the players - for United's decline. He then said: "If we cannot change that really fast, we should give our place to different persons".

United co-owner Ratcliffe, chief executive Omar Berrada and the rest of the club's hierarchy will assess Amorim's position once the season ends - even if United beat Tottenham in the European final. Amorim has won just six of his 25 Premier League games with this season United's worst since they were relegated in 1974.

Mourinho has led three Premier League sides in his career - Prior to managing United he led Chelsea in two separate stints and then took over at Tottenham less than a year after his sacking in Manchester.

Since leaving north London Mourinho has coached Roma and is now in Turkey, but looks set to finish the season without a trophy. Now 62, the Portuguese coach has struggled to have the kind of influence he did when he was leading Inter Milan to Champions League success.

If United do axe Amorim but opt against re-appointing Mourinho the bookies have Ipswich boss Kieran McKenna, who was once an assistant in Manchester, among the favourites. Gareth Southgate is also being linked and has not taken a job since leaving England.

headline: Arsenal told 'time is ticking' for Viktor Gyokeres transfer with Man Utd ready to swoop
body: Sporting striker Viktor Gyokeres could begin to look at alternative options, including a switch to Manchester United, if Arsenal don't quickly back up their interest. The striker has been lighting up Lisbon with his incredible goalscoring prowess since he made the jump from Coventry City.
Under the guidance of Ruben Amorim, Gyokeres became one of the most feared goalscorers in Europe, with 95 goals in 100 appearances for the club.

Following Amorim's departure, rumours are rife that Gyokeres will seek pastures new when the season comes to a close. Arsenal have been heavily with the Swede, with reports suggesting that personal terms had even been agreed with the player.

David Ornstein, during a chat with NBC Sports, offered a new update on the situation. "Viktor Gyokeres remains in the mix for Arsenal. He is a player that Arsenal's sporting director Andrea Berta really likes," he explained.

Ornstein hinted that United may step in if Arsenal delay any longer. But with a probable hefty price tag over £60m, it's likely Amorim will need to secure Champions League qualification by winning the Europa League to bolster his budget.

It is understood that the club's current strategy is to pursue Ipswich Town's Liam Delap in the summer transfer window. Despite Ipswich's relegation from the Premier League, Delap's strong performances have marked him out as a viable target to bolster the club's attacking line-up.

Thanks to a relegation clause in his contract, Delap is expected to be available for around £30m. Wolverhampton Wanderers talisman Matheus Cunha is also believed to be high on the list of targets for United's recruitment team.

It promises to be a pivotal summer at Old Trafford after their worst-ever Premier League season. On Sunday, after slumping to their 17th defeat of the season, Amorim hinted that unless he can turn it around - he should be replaced.

He said: "I don't want to talk about the players. I'm talking about myself and the culture in the club and the culture in the team. I have that feeling. We need to change that and we need to be really strong in the summer and to be brave.
"Because we cannot have a season like this next year. If the feeling is still here, we should give the space to different persons."

headline: MARSHALL: Ruben Amorim is ignoring the elephant in the room at Manchester United
body: In Ruben Amorim's brutally honest press conference after Manchester United's latest Premier League defeat, there was one glaring omission from the subjects discussed. It covered culture, embarrassment, standards and what needs to change.
But there, sitting in the corner, was the elephant in the room. Is this system ever going to work in English football? And perhaps more importantly, is this style ever going to work for United?

Amorim has made it abundantly clear he has no plans to abandon his 3-4-2-1, so it has become the forgotten issue. There is no point asking about it when you know what the answer is going to be. And there is evidence that three-man defences can succeed here. Antonio Conte did it with Chelsea, and Oliver Glasner and Vitor Pereira have had some success with Crystal Palace and Wolves this season.

But the version Amorim has delivered to domestic audiences so far is slow, predictable and defensive. It is simple to play against because the build-up is easy to read, and the pace of the games doesn't allow enough players to get forward. In European contests, when the pace is slower, when both teams seek possession, and pressing systems aren't always as intense, Amorim's United have time to get their structure right.

That isn't happening against Premier League teams. In the league under Amorim, United have won just six of their 25 games, losing 13 of them. It's two-thirds of a season, and the form record reads like that of a team battling relegation. Add in cup games and United lost to Tottenham in the Carabao Cup, beat Leicester City at Old Trafford in the FA Cup, and had a penalty shoot-out win against Arsenal and a defeat against Fulham.

It is a dreadful record that contrasts sharply with the Europa League performances. On Sunday, Amorim blamed a lack of urgency in the Premier League compared to Europe, but a final in Bilbao against domestic opposition might well be instructive. Amorim's United have already been beaten twice by Spurs.

If the Europa League version of United turn up and get the better of Tottenham for once, it will give credence to Amorim's idea that something has been missing from Premier League games. If it's a repeat of what we've seen on these shores, then his tactical set-up has to come into sharper focus once more.

But there should already be alarm bells ringing. It's easy to write recent defeats off as abandoning the Premier League season to focus on Europe, but team selections have remained strong, and this is not a new phenomenon either.

United lost five of their six Premier League games in December. Under Amorim, they have failed to score against Arsenal, Bournemouth, Wolves (twice), Newcastle, Crystal Palace, Tottenham, Nottingham Forest and now West Ham. Their struggles at Old Trafford are particularly revealing.

No club fears the Theatre of Dreams anymore, but where Amorim's side have struggled most of all is in making the running against inferior teams at home, when the onus is on them to dictate pace and tempo. They have been too slow, too easy to defend against, and too simple to pick off.

In the space of six months, Nottingham Forest, Bournemouth, Newcastle, Brighton, Crystal Palace, Wolves and West Ham have won at Old Trafford in the Premier League. That is a truly wretched record. The only teams United have beaten at home in the Premier League in that time are Southampton and Ipswich, and neither was easy.

It's too easy an excuse to bury heads in the sand and point out that Amorim just doesn't have the players to make it work. That is a simplistic excuse and frankly, an embarrassing one for an elite-level coach. He could have been adaptable, but even without changing the system, he should be performing better with the squad he has.

On Sunday, Amorim suggested he could be fired if next season starts badly. The clock has certainly started ticking. The question for United is whether they retain enough faith to commit this summer's transfer budget to a system that a predecessor would tear up.
United would improve under the Portuguese with more attacking wing-backs and a better striker. They would be more threatening with a creative playmaker.
But would that solve the structural problems? And if the solution to raising that kind of money is selling Kobbie Mainoo or Alejandro Garnacho, is it worth the risk?

Amorim retains the backing of United supporters. He has been an open, honest and critical communicator and has steered the club to a European final. But there are still questions that won't go away and doubts that are starting to grow.

headline: RAILSTON: Ruben Amorim hints something will be 'more important' than transfers at Manchester United
body: Ruben Amorim has suggested implementing the right mentality at Manchester United will be more important than signing players this summer.
United have endured their worst season in Premier League history and Amorim is hoping to win the Europa League, which would grant entry into the Champions League next season.

Playing in the Champions League would be a huge boost for the club's broadcast revenue and make it easier to attract players this summer. Amorim wasn't supported in the January transfer window and he will need heavy backing in the summer window to get United heading in the right direction again.
United need a new striker, a right wing-back and a new midfielder, while other positions need to be strengthened, but Amorim has argued instilling the right mentality is just as important.
"There are some things that we can't change in the summer with transfers," said Amorim. "It's the feeling in this club, the way we see this club, it's that real feeling that we cannot lose a match.
"It's impossible for us to play at home and lose, this kind of feeling, we have to change that and not thinking about transfers. That is something more profound than just changing people.

"We need to address this and we are doing that also. People cannot see that, but we are changing a lot of things in Carrington, the way we work here and the behaviour you must have in this club... The way we connect the academy with our team.
"All these things that you cannot see, we are working on that. So we need to forget about the final and try be better in the game against Chelsea because we have a lot to improve."
Amorim was asked when he realised 'things' weren't right at United and said: "I cannot tell the moment, but you have that feeling when you see things and see the way we play.
"But again, it seems like I'm pushing toward the players, and I'm responsible. It's hard to find another word, I'm really embarrassed. Something is wrong with the way we are playing football."
He continued: "The last game [West Ham] is something we felt a lot, especially because we won against Athletic Bilbao and we had an opportunity to maintain the momentum.
"We had several moments like this in the season and we dropped. But we are addressing that since day one, so Chelsea is another opportunity to play the game, perform well and show character."

headline: Dan Ashworth set for return to football after shock Manchester United departure
body: Dan Ashworth is set to take a new job with the Football Association, according to the BBC.
Ashworth made a shock departure from his position as Manchester United's sporting director in December, and he is set to take up his first role since his short tenure at Old Trafford.

The 54-year-old is set to become the head of elite men's and women's development at the FA. Ashworth spent six years working for the FA as their director of elite development between 2012 and 2018, and part of his new role will be to oversee the development of homegrown coaches in England.
Ashworth is also expected to oversee the next stage of the refurbishment of St George's Park.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe described Ashworth as one of "the top sporting directors in the world" when he joined United, however, he spectacularly left the club after just five months in his role.

He was expected to overhaul United's recruitment and usher in a new era following Ratcliffe's investment and his exit was a shock. Ashworth reported to CEO Omar Berrada during his time as sporting director and the final decision to end his contract was said to be mutual.
Ashworth was involved in United's recruitment last summer, which saw over £200million spent on Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Manuel Ugarte, Matthijs De Ligt and Noussair Mazraou.
The decision to keep Erik ten Hag after a poor campaign was also contentious. The Dutchman was backed by club executives but Ashworth was quoted on his contract extension.
Ten Hag oversaw an eighth-place finish in the Premier League and recorded a minus goal difference. United contacted other managers but kept him after the FA Cup final.
The Dutchman was subsequently sacked just months into the 2024/25 season.

headline: LUCKHURST: Matchgoers' support of five Manchester United players speaks volumes about the rest of the squad
body: "We need to be really strong in the summer and be brave," Ruben Amorim stressed. It would take a brave man not to gut this maligned Manchester United squad.

United's 16th position in the Premier League and 17 defeats are unforgivable, regardless of their Europa League progress. The truest gauge of a team is their league form and United's has not been this appalling since people wore flares and listened to Slade.

Amorim merits backing but, irrespective of whether United return from Bilbao with a new attraction for the club museum, the scrutiny on his position will be intense before each of those first three autumnal international breaks in the first third of next season.

He admitted on Sunday that if the complacent culture continues to linger next season he should be sacked. Amorim has the matchgoers onside, so much so his name is chanted more regularly than any of the players.

United supporters are often dignified in expressing their disapproval. It took a 4-1 humbling by Watford for them to specifically boo Ole Gunnar Solskjaer at Vicarage Road. In front of the Sir Elton John Stand, Solskjaer was barely still standing.

Separating the head coach from the players signals a vote of confidence for Amorim and a vote of no confidence for the majority of players. Bruno Fernandes, Casemiro, Harry Maguire and Leny Yoro are in the good books. All four have been serenaded recently. Amad is a firm fan favourite.

Amad and Fernandes renewed their contracts in the last year, Maguire had his extended until 2026 and Yoro only arrived in July. Casemiro's Europa League pedigree has endeared him to supporters who appreciate his commitment and gutsiness after 18 months in decline.

The purported poster boys of the new United, Alejandro Garnacho and Kobbie Mainoo, have had trying campaigns and the bond between academy starlets and supporters is not as ardent as it was a year ago. A rejected bid for Garnacho and a rejected contract by Mainoo have doubtless contributed. Both players' agents were sat among the United squad's family and friends in San Mames two weeks ago.

As for the rest, fans would not kick up a fuss if the majority left. United acquired a dependable squad player in Noussair Mazraoui, Ayden Heaven showed promise before injury and Lisandro Martinez is an undeniable asset when fit.

Then there are the frozen assets - those who freeze in the United shirt. Serie A remains a dumping ground for English clubs and United have to write off at least one of the £108.5million misfits Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee.

Hojlund has eked three goals in 32 games and this is his second season. Zirkzee creditably rallied after his ignominious first-half substitution against Newcastle United but United are not going to get to where they aspire to be with him in the team. The two forwards bought from Europe's boot should be given the boot.

Manchester City's dominance under Pep Guardiola was underpinned by them clearing the decks at full back in the summer of 2017. Bacary Sagna, Pablo Zabaleta and Gael Clichy were released while Aleksandar Kolarov was sold. City invested £126.5m to recruit Kyle Walker, Benjamin Mendy and Danilo.

By City's sixth game of the 2017-18 season, Walker and Mendy had tallied more assists than Sagna, Zabaleta, Kolarov and Clichy had done between them in the previous campaign. Although Mendy succumbed to an anterior cruciate ligament injury in City's eighth fixture, the die had been cast. Fabian Delph came in as an auxiliary left back and the front-footed approach had a profound effect on serial matchwinning wingers Raheem Sterling and Leroy Sane.

Walker is a City great. Mendy is not held in remotely similar esteem for obvious reasons and without him Guardiola reinvented the wheel at left back. Delph and then Oleksandr Zinchenko had successful stints out of position there. City have still not signed a recognisable left back since Mendy.

United, meanwhile, still have a left back who joined 11 years ago. They are saddled with Luke Shaw, approaching the last two years of his contract. Victor Lindelof's outstayed welcome will end after eight years and the United hierarchy must have breathed a sigh of relief when they discovered that there was not a one-year option on Christian Eriksen's contract.

Loanees Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho and Antony have to be shifted permanently. United may have a similar waiting game with Rashford to last summer's with Sancho, who joined Chelsea at the 11th hour. Europa Conference League finalist Antony is at least creating a market that should ensure his fee prevents United from making a loss on him under the Premier League's profitability and sustainability rules.

Casemiro's European form cannot hoodwink United. If they lose to Tottenham in Bilbao, no European football next season would effectively render Casemiro more redundant than some of the staff the club are letting go. The 33-year-old's revival has been restricted to the Europa League.

Should Casemiro stay or go, Amorim would be sanguine. His perception of the Brazilian has altered drastically since the end of the winter transfer window. As instrumental as Casemiro was against Real Sociedad, Lyon and Athletic Bilbao, hardly any clubs would stump up the £15m United require and match Casemiro's handsome £300,000-a-week salary.
Unlike Manuel Ugarte against Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Casemiro is brave, at least.

headline: Man United transfer news LIVE - Sheikh Jassim ‘update’, Delap boost, Matheus Cunha 'agreement'
body: Hello and welcome to our Manchester United live blog, where we’ll bring you all the transfer news, views, and gossip on Tuesday, May 13.

It was another disappointing domestic weekend for Ruben Amorim's side, as they suffered a 2-0 home defeat to West Ham in the Premier League. They will travel to Stamford Bridge next to take on Chelsea on Friday night before the crucial Europa League final on May 21.

Off the pitch, work is already underway as Amorim prepares to oversee his first full summer transfer window. One of the key areas the club will look to strengthen is their attack, with the likes of Viktor Gyokeres, Matheus Cunha, Liam Delap, and Victor Osimhen all on their radar.
Goodnight United fans!
We'll have you covered for more United transfer news and gossip tomorrow!
Manchester United have reportedly decided against holding an end of season awards dinner at the end of the season.

The club traditionally holds a gala dinner at Old Trafford each May as players across the teams receive awards. However, The Athletic have reported that the awards will be handed out on the pitch before the Premier League game of the season against Aston Villa.
Manchester United co-owners the Glazer family could hand Sheikh Jassim the chance to launch a fresh takeover bid.

The Americans will soon obtain the power to activate their drag-along rights, meaning the majority shareholders could force minority shareholders, such as Sir Jim Ratcliffe, to sell their shares when the majority sells their stake to a third party, according to The Athletic.
It is claimed these drag-along rights will come into effect in around three months' time, which would mark 18 months since Ratcliffe's minority takeover of the club was finalised.

This development could force Sheikh Jassim back to the negotiating table, with the Glazers potentially able to offer him the chance to push Sir Jim Ratcliffe to offload his shares unless he can match any incoming offers.
Manchester United are the frontrunners to land Ipswich Town striker Liam Delap in the summer.
Newcastle and Chelsea are also following the striker closely.
Watford have announced the appointment of Paulo Pezzolano as their new head coach.
The 42-year-old Uruguayan succeeds Tom Cleverley, who was sacked on May 6 following the Hornets' disappointing 14th-place finish in the Sky Bet Championship.
Pezzolano becomes Watford's 18th permanent boss since Gianfranco Zola left in December 2013.
Real Madrid are reportedly preparing to launch a bid for Benfica and former Manchester United left-back Alvaro Carreras.
Atletico Madrid are also said to be interested in the full-back. It's worth noting that United have a significant sell-on clause and a buy-back option worth £15million.
Bruno Lage, Benfica's boss, has publicly addressed the situation, saying: "When I arrived here, Carreras was a flop and now Atletico and Real Madrid are interested.

"What is more important is what we think about the player. He is a player who has contributed to the team, who has been used the most by us, and I am pleased with him. He is very important to our dynamic (…) Regarding Carreras, I said he was a flop because I didn't know the player."
Every dog has its day and Altay Bayindir's came against Arsenal at the Emirates in January.

Bayindir started in the FA Cup third round against Arsenal and delivered a heroic performance, making crucial saves in normal time and saving two penalties in the shootout victory. The truth is Bayindir is below the level required to fill in for Andre Onana.

He has conceded 18 goals in nine starts in all competitions this season and hasn't proven himself as a reliable back-up goalkeeper. The Turkish international was calamitous against Tottenham in the Carabao Cup in December. He had a night to forget and made mistakes, conceding four goals in London.

Amorim bravely handed another chance to Bayindir against Arsenal in the FA Cup. Bayindir had already been responsible for United crashing out of a cup competition, so Amorim rolled the dice with his team selection, but at least he was able to deliver on the other side of North London.
Read more here.
Ruben Amorim has talked with the Man United board ahead of a huge transfer window.

"It's the way we face competition, the way we suffer, the way we get mad because we're losing and the way we protect the goal. These things we need to improve and sometimes it's just inside the pitch, it's outside the pitch.
"That feeling I'm talking about, fighting towards the end and facing competition, it's not ok to lose and it's not ok to draw. It doesn't matter if we can change our league position or not."
Antoine Semenyo has held talks with Manchester United over a potential summer transfer, according to talkSPORT.
The Ghanianian, who scored in both fixtures against United this season, has attracted interest after impressing at Bournemouth, netting nine goals and five assists in 35 league matches.
Semenyo does not have a release clause but Bournemouth value him at £50million - a fee that would represent a huge deal of profit for the south coast club.
Dan Ashworth is set to take a new job with the Football Association, according to the BBC.
Ashworth made a shock departure from his position as Manchester United's sporting director in December, and he is set to take up his first role since his short tenure at Old Trafford.

The 54-year-old is set to become the head of elite men's and women's development at the FA. Ashworth spent six years working for the FA as their director of elite development between 2012 and 2018, and part of his new role will be to oversee the development of homegrown coaches in England.
Fenerbahce are showing interest in signing Manchester United forward Jadon Sancho, according to Turkish outlet Yeni Asir.
The England international has spent the season at Chelsea but he is expected to return to Old Trafford in the summer.
This is after the Blues agreed to pay a £5million penalty to avoid signing him in a £25m permanent deal following a difficult second half of the campaign.

Now, it has reported that Jose Mourinho has approved of a potential deal to take Sancho to Fenerbahce. The Super Lig club are in the market for a new winger with Allan Saint-Maximim heading back to parent club Al-Ahli at the end of his loan.
Richard Keys has claimed that Ruben Amorim has "all but resigned" from his role as head coach at Manchester United with his comments after their 2-0 defeat against West Ham.
"I don't want to talk about the players," he said. "I'm talking about myself and the culture in the club and the culture in the team. I have that feeling.

"We need to change that and we need to be really strong in the summer and to be brave. Because we cannot have a season like this next year. If the feeling is still here, we should give the space to different persons."
And beIN Sports broadcaster Keys believes such a stance vindicates his belief that Amorim is trying to get the sack.
"How long have I been saying Ruben Amorim has been trying to get the sack? You all laughed at me," Keys wrote in his latest blog.
"Well, now what? Because this weekend, he all but resigned. It's hard to interpret his post-match comments after the West Ham defeat any other way."
Manchester United are close to a verbal agreement and personal terms with Wolves forward Matheus Cunha, according to Goal Brasil's Valentin Furlan.
Ruben Amorim's side have been linked with a move for Cunha after impressing at Wolves this season. He has scored 15 goals and added six assists in 31 Premier League matches.
Now, it has emerged that a deal is edging close. Cunha has a £62.5million release clause in his Wolves contract and United are expected to trigger that and bring him to Old Trafford.
Arsenal made a late move to attempt to hijack the deal, but that has appeared to be brushed to the side.
Former Chelsea forward Diego Costa has heaped praise on Antony following a successful loan spell at Real Betis and has backed him to return to the Brazil squad this summer.
Antony left Manchester United to join Betis on loan back in January and he has since impressed, scoring eight times and adding four assists in 22 appearances across competitions.
Costa has told The National: "So Antony lacked a little patience. He also went through a lot of messed up things. I know about family issues.

"So the kid's head was very messed up because he's very talented. Antony is very good, and look, now that he's happy, he's calm, he's having an impressive season. It's very easy to criticise from the outside, but as players, our heads count for a lot. If we're not clean, it ends up affecting the field.

"He had a very difficult problem behind him because of the accusation against him but now he's fine. He's calm. He's happy and confident. Look how he's doing at Betis. If he carries on like this he's a player who’s going to be there to play in the World Cup."
Manchester United are expected to keep Ruben Amorim as head coach next season even if they lose the Europa League final against Tottenham, according to The Guardian.

Amorim has endured a mixed time at Old Trafford since arriving from Sporting CP and replacing Erik ten Hag in November. The Portuguese has won just six and drawn six of his 25 Premier League matches in charge - a run that has seen them drop down to 16th in the table.

However, it's not been all doom and gloom for United since Amorim has arrived. In the Europa League, United have been excellent, and have won nine and drawn five of their 14 fixtures in that competition.

There has been talk that, considering their dire Premier League form, Amorim could face the sack if United lose the Europa League final against Spurs and are denied Champions League football next season.
However, that is NOT the case, as it's reported that Amorim will keep his job regardless of the result against Ange Postecoglou's side in Bilbao.
The United board feel that Amorim deserves the summer transfer window to improve his squad and sign players more suited to his system.
Manchester United could receive a boost in their potential pursuit of Victor Osimhen this summer, as Napoli have reportedly made a move for his replacement.

Osimhen, who spent this season on loan at Galatasaray following a public falling out with Napoli manager Antonio Conte, is among the players set to depart the club at the end of the season. He has been linked with a move to Old Trafford as Ruben Amorim looks to bolster his attacking options.
Napoli, meanwhile, have already identified Osimhen's replacement - Lille’s Jonathan David, who is set to leave the French club on a free transfer when his contract expires.

Fabrizio Romano states that the Italian giants have submitted a proposal to the striker and advanced talks are currently ongoing. He also adds that 'key' details are yet to be clarified before David makes a decision on his future.
Man United legend Rio Ferdinand has opened up on his 'crazy' recent health scare that forced him to sit out of his TNT Sport punditry duties.

Speaking out for the first time, Ferdinand offered an update and a scary behind the scenes of the ordeal that left him hospitalised. "My wife, the women in my family, will never know… man flu. That’s what it’s really about, man flu," he said, speaking on the Rio Ferdinand presents YouTube channel.

"I had a mad virus, bro. I thought lights were out at some point, I thought it was gonna happen. I thought I was minutes away from lights out, seriously. I was in my house, I was in my bed like this [pained expression] and I couldn’t even open my eyes.

"Then, the headache I had… I don’t get migraines or nothing else so I don’t know what they’re like. I thought my head was in a vice and my eyes were going to pop out. Then, I was being sick, projectile vomiting in the toilet, I got back to bed and I was having vertigo.
"I was holding onto the sheets, I didn’t know where I was. It was crazy. I had to go to hospital and the doctor even said to me, 'Do you want an ambulance', so that’s when I knew.
"He went, ‘We’re going to get your brain scanned. I thought it was a virus or a flu or something so when he mentioned brain scan and the ambulance, the panic was nuts.
"I went to hospital and I was in there for a few days. I couldn’t even enjoy the hospital food. The soup and the ice cream normally does wonders."
Gary Pallister believes the current Man United squad has not done Ruben Amorim any favours as he tries to turn the club's misfortunes around.
"I think we have to wait to see what kind of stamp he put on it," Pallister told Betway. "I think it’s very difficult to judge him this year with the team he’s got.

"He's tried to change it to his own style and his own tactics, and as of now, that’s not worked. He needs to bring in players that will be more comfortable in the system, and bring more character into the side.

"So, I think we’ve got to give him the amount of time that he deserves, and I think any manager would deserve, but he's only going to get a certain time now and in the next season before people do start judging him."
The Daily Mail claim the Brazilian midfielder will receive a pay rise if Man United win the Europa League this month.

It's reported that his wages will increase by 25 percent if United qualify for the Champions League next season. This would bring his weekly earnings close to £500,000, reportedly the same amount Cristiano Ronaldo earned during his second stint at the club.
Arsenal reportedly appear eager to gain an edge over rivals Man United in the race to sign Sporting Clube de Portugal star Gyokeres.

Portuguese newspaper A Bola claims that Arsenal want to lure the Swedish striker with a move and have offered him a £7million-a-year (€8m) salary after tax. The report goes on to say that Arsenal haven't made a formal bid yet and are not expected to do so immediately, as Gyokeres is focused on winning the Liga Portugal title and the Taca de Portugal with the Lions.
Despite his full focus on the task, it's said that Gyokeres is aware of the latest developments. It's thought that the proposal has been received as 'acceptable'.
Sporting's final match of the season is on May 25, and the Gunners are said to be 'ready' to table a €70–€75 million (£58m–£63m) offer once the campaign concludes.
According to El Desmarque, Johnny Cardoso will have the final say on whether he leaves Real Betis for the Premier League this summer.

The 23-year-old’s £21 million release clause becomes active in the summer, amid interest from Manchester United. While Cardoso is reportedly happy in Seville, the same report suggests that Champions League qualification could influence his decision, with Tottenham and Atlético Madrid also showing interest.
Manchester United are reportedly planning to keep celebrations low-key if they win the Europa League trophy.
While some may argue that winning the European trophy could salvage their season, United have reportedly ruled out holding an open-top bus parade if they win the competition.
According to The Times, any potential success would be marked with a barbecue at Carrington for the players, staff and their families.
The decision comes as co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe continues to implement cost-cutting measures at Old Trafford, with United also facing a tight schedule.
Read more here.
Manchester United's domestic campaign continues to plumb new depths following the weekend loss to West Ham.

The result was United's 17th of a woeful Premier League season and dropped them to 17th in the table. Ruben Amorim's side are now seven without a win in the top fight and have only won one match against a non-relegated club (at Fulham in January) since the dramatic derby day comeback at the Etihad in December.

The numbers make grim reading and while the Europa League final against Tottenham offers a chance at salvation and the prospect of Champions League football next season, United's form in continental competition - where they are unbeaten this term - is only papering over the cracks.

A dramatic rebuild is needed and required but will cost money United don't have. Winning the final in Bilbao next week will earn £10.95million in prizemoney along with the riches of the Champions League.
But United's financial position is worsening by the week in the Premier League.
Read more here.
Man United have been handed a boost amid reports they have 'an interest' in signing Bournemouth forward Antoine Semenyo.
The report claims that United have gone ahead of Liverpool and other Premier League clubs in the battle to sign Semenyo, who is said to be valued at around £70million.
According to talkSPORT, the Man United hierarchy has no plans to replace the Portuguese manager this summer.
Massimiliano Allegri has recently emerged as the bookmakers' favourite to succeed him, as United's poor form continues.
However, talkSPORT reports that Amorim's superiors have no immediate plans to assess his position at the club.
Fabrizio Romano reports that Bayern Munich have gained the upper hand in the race to sign Tah on a free transfer amid Man United's interest.
Taking to Instagram, he wrote: "Bayern have sent official proposal to Jonathan Tah to join on a free deal.

"Negotiations ongoing for the German defender who’s leaving Leverkusen as free agent, FC Bayern are on it since end of April with a formal proposal sent to Tah. Barcelona have been keen on signing Tah for months but Araujo, Christensen, Eric García staying changed plans in January with deal not signed at this stage."

The first window will run from June 1 to June 10, while the second will begin on June 16 and close on September 1. The extended duration of this window is also believed to have played a role in the change of timings.
According to Football Espana, Real Betis are starting to fear that they may not be able to sign Antony permanently even if they qualify for the Champions League.
It is understood that both Atletico Madrid and Juventus are showing an interest in the Brazilian thanks to his brilliant form in Seville.
Villarreal, who occupy the last Champions League spot, are thought to see Antony as more of a priority as do Betis and Atletico.
Antony's current club are believed to want him on a loan deal next season but we understand that United want to sell him.
TBR Football state Ipswich Town striker Liam Delap's preference would be to sign for United over Chelsea in the summer transfer window.
The forward will be available for £30m at the end of this season thanks to Ipswich's relegation and we understand the striker is a top target for Ineos this summer.

headline: Marcus Rashford given Barcelona transfer green light as Man United decision awaits
body: Barcelona sporting director Deco has freshly admitted that his club are lacking in depth behind wing players Lamine Yamal and Raphinha, amid speculation linking the Spanish champions elect with a move for Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford.

However, due to their ongoing financial difficulties and their lack of interest in a loan, they did not pursue a deal and the 27-year-old instead completed the short-term switch to Aston Villa from United.

Now, whilst ESPN, who Deco was talking to, say Barca are not expected to make any 'major' signings again over the summer window, the sporting director suggested his club is short of players in the Englishman's role.
"If we can improve, that's always an option, but the key is to consolidate what we have for the coming years.
"Suddenly we feel quite dependent on Raphinha and Lamine. Maybe we need similar players, a solution for them [when they're not available]," the Portuguese confessed.
"But the squad is quite balanced and we have a lot of good players coming through the youth teams as well."
It is believed to be Rashford's dream to play for Barcelona one day as links continue to crop up approaching the next transfer window.
For now he is with Villa until the end of the season, where manager Unai Emery personally pushed for the signing as he felt he could help the attacker rediscover his form.
Rashford has scored four goals and provided six assists in 17 matches in the West Midlands, but recently suffered a hamstring injury that has hampered his progress.
The England international jetted off to Dubai to undergo warm weather recovery training with his season perhaps ended.

headline: Manchester United star Amad shows true colours as Sunderland seal dramatic play-off win
body: Manchester United winger Amad returned to his former loan side Sunderland to cheer them on for a crucial Championship play-off second-leg clash with Coventry City.

Amad, 22, signed at Old Trafford in 2020. Having completed the notable achievement of breaking into the senior team of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, it was decided for his betterment loans to Rangers and then Sunderland were ideal.

It was that season-long spell at the Stadium of Light that the United loanee's career in English football advanced, scoring 14 goals and providing four assists as the Black Cats' top scorer, though he could not inspire them to play-off glory as they crashed out at the semi-final stage to Luton Town that year.

Back in the four-club showpiece, Sunderland have been up against Coventry City managed by Frank Lampard. They won the first away leg 2-1 with a late strike and returned home for the second meeting, where Amad was in attendance showing his support.

The Ivorian posted to his Instagram story showing his view from the stands behind Regis Le Bris and Lampard's dugouts, including the 'fingers crossed' emoji as he wished for his former side to make the Wembley Stadium final.
He was also picked up by broadcaster's cameras viewing the action, much like Harry Maguire was at his former club Sheffield United 24 hours before.
It was not going how Amad may have hoped as a solitary second-half Coventry goal on the night had sent the tie to extra-time with a 2-2 aggregate scoreline.

However former teammate Dan Ballard rose highest from a 132nd-minute corner and with virtually one of the final touches of the game headed Sunderland to the play-off final. Pandemonium ensued with a pitch invasion from supporters.

Last December speaking to Inside United via Sunderland of his fond memories, the United player said: "Sunderland was my second time on loan, and I have a lot of beautiful things to say about the Club.
"They supported me and were unbelievable with me and my family and tried to help me in everything – on and off the pitch.
"They give me a lot of love and I enjoyed every moment of playing for Sunderland – I was so happy to be part of it.
"I wish everyone at Sunderland the best for now and for the future because they are a beautiful Club."
Amad has since gone on to break through into United's Premier League side under Erik ten Hag and was a key player for Ruben Amorim before injury kept him out for a good portion of the season.
Beforehand he had registered nine goals and nine assists, so his club will have been thankful that he returned ahead of schedule with a goal against Brentford this month.
Amad has been building up his fitness since to be able to play an integral role in next week's Europa League final.

headline: Ruben Amorim confirms board talks as Man United summer transfer plan is clear amid Ashworth return
body: Manchester United are gearing up for a busy summer in the transfer market as Ruben Amorim continues to shape his rebuild of the club.

United's league form this season has been dire but they are just eight days out from a Europa League final where victory would see them end this miserable campaign with a trophy and Champions League qualification.
And it has been a busy day on the United beat with Amorim discussing conversations he has held with the United hierarchy amid increasing scrutiny surrounding his performance as manager.
United's summer transfer plans have been outlined, while there was a surprise return to football for a former United man.
Here is a look at the key Manchester United headlines on Tuesday, May 13.
Ruben Amorim has talked with Manchester United's board about what the team needs to be "so much better."

"It's the way we face competition, the way we suffer, the way we get mad because we're losing and the way we protect the goal. These things we need to improve and sometimes it's just inside the pitch, it's outside the pitch.
"That feeling I'm talking about, fighting towards the end and facing competition, it's not ok to lose and it's not ok to draw. It doesn't matter if we can change our league position or not."
Amorim continued: "That feeling is nothing about confidence, it's about the belief and understanding that we are in Manchester United and we don't want to be the worst in the league.

"Our position [16th in the table] is unacceptable. For me, that is not a lack of confidence, it's something more profound, and I talk with the board and with everybody, even with the fans, in every moment. I have a clear feeling of what this team needs to be so much better.
"That helps me to maintain that level of not going down too much, or so high in some moments".
Read the full story, here.
With the outcome of the clash with Spurs deciding whether they will be in Europe or not next season, United have had to plan for two scenarios ahead of this summer.

Speaking at the unveiling of United's new stadium plans in March, chief executive Omar Berrada said: "There's no doubt that if we qualify to the Champions League, we will have more revenues and we'll have more capacity to invest in the team.
"But we are putting in place various financial measures to allow us to go and invest at the summer, even if we're outside of Europe."

Dan Ashworth is set to take a new job with the Football Association, according to the BBC.
Ashworth made a shock departure from his position as Manchester United's sporting director in December, and he is set to take up his first role since his short tenure at Old Trafford.

The 54-year-old is set to become the head of elite men's and women's development at the FA. Ashworth spent six years working for the FA as their director of elite development between 2012 and 2018, and part of his new role will be to oversee the development of homegrown coaches in England.
Ashworth is also expected to oversee the next stage of the refurbishment of St George's Park.
Sir Jim Ratcliffe described Ashworth as one of "the top sporting directors in the world" when he joined United, however, he spectacularly left the club after just five months in his role.

headline: Marseille make huge Mason Greenwood transfer exit decision as Man United reunion tipped
body: Mason Greenwood's future at Marseille has been placed into serious doubt after reports in France claimed offers will be listened to for the 23-year-old this summer.

The former Manchester United winger joined the French side last summer and has played a crucial part in their qualification for the Champions League. At the weekend, Greenwood scored a massive goal in their 3-1 win over Le Havre to confirm their spot among Europe's elite.
In his first season in France, the 23-year-old has scored 19 Ligue 1 goals. Only Paris Saint-Germain's Ousmane Dembele has outscored him, but that hasn't stopped criticism coming his way.

Greenwood's work rate and attitude have been questioned by some supporters, while manager Roberto De Zerbi has publicly criticised him at times. Earlier this week, it was claimed that at least two Premier League teams were considering a move for Greenwood, who could reunite with his former United teammates by playing against them for another English club.
Now, RMC Sport have reported that Marseille aren't desperate to retain the former United star and would consider a strong offer for him at the end of the season.

Greenwood only cost Marseille £27million last summer but it's understood that United have a sell-on clause worth around 40 to 50 per cent. The clause could prove to be a significant money maker for United, should he be snapped up in the summer.

headline: Ruben Amorim Man United sack latest as 'decision made' and meeting scheduled
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim has come under pressure after another dismal defeat. The Reds were beaten for the 17th time in the Premier League this season, following a 2-0 defeat against West Ham on Sunday.

Amorim has endured a mixed time at Old Trafford since arriving from Sporting CP and replacing Erik ten Hag in November. The Portuguese has won just six and drawn six of his 25 league matches in charge - a run that has seen them drop down to 16th in the table, one point ahead of Tottenham in 17th.
However, it's not been all doom and gloom for United since Amorim joined. In the Europa League, United have been excellent, and have won nine and drawn five of their 14 fixtures in that competition.
They face Tottenham in the final of Europe's second tier competition next Wednesday, having beat Real Sociedad, Lyon and Athletic Club de Bilbao to reach this stage of the tournament.
Manchester United are expected to keep Ruben Amorim as head coach next season even if they lose the Europa League final against Tottenham, according to The Guardian.

There has been talk that, considering their dire Premier League form, Amorim could face the sack if United lose the Europa League final against Spurs and are denied Champions League football next season.

However, that is reported not to be the case, with Amorim set to keep his job regardless of the result against Ange Postecoglou's side in Bilbao. The United board feel that Amorim deserves the summer transfer window to improve his squad and sign players more suited to his system.

Manchester United will review Ruben Amorim's position this summer, even if he wins the Europa League, according to The Mirror. The move comes after Amorim put extra pressure on himself after suggesting he might not be the right man for the job following their defeat against West Ham.
United co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe, chief executive Omar Berrada and the rest of the club's board will assess Amorim's role at the end of the season.

Even if United beat Tottenham in next Wednesday's Europa League final to secure Champions League football, Amorim's position is set to be evaluated following a dire league campaign and his post-match comments.

Ruben Amorim's job at Manchester United is safe, regardless of the result in the Europa League final, as per talkSPORT. United insiders insist that the club are preparing for the long-haul with Amorim.
It's claimed that Amorim will be backed in the summer with a deal for Wolves forward Matheus Cunha advanced and confidence is growing regarding a potential move for Ipswich Town's Liam Delap.

"Our position [16th in the table] is unacceptable. For me, that is not a lack of confidence, it's something more profound, and I talk with the board and with everybody, even with the fans, in every moment. I have a clear feeling of what this team needs to be so much better.
"That helps me to maintain that level of not going down too much, or so high in some moments".

headline: Manchester United confirm departure of trophy-winning coach
body: Manchester United coach Adam Lawrence has left his position as Under-18 manager.

Sources have said Lawrence is open to working in a first-team environment or a fresh academy challenge for the next step of his career. The 39-year-old has been offered roles in English Football League first-team coaching set-ups and is currently weighing up his next move ahead of the new season.
Lawrence's departure is unrelated to the club-wide redundancies and sources close to the coach say he is happy to work anywhere geographically after spending four years in Manchester.

In a statement, Lawrence said: "It has been a privilege to work for Manchester United. It has been a very special few years with this group; I’ve been fortunate to work with many of this season’s Under-18s right through from the Under-16s level and witness their growth as people as well as players.

“During the last two years, all the staff across the Professional Development Phase can be very proud of the work we have done to support the players. The style of play, the focus on individual development and the culture of the academy that we have supported; it has been a real privilege to play my part in helping the group.
“I’m now ready for the next challenge but I’ll always cherish the memories made at this great club and can’t wait to see what the future holds for the players I’ve had the pleasure of working with.”

Head of the academy, Nick Cox, said: "Adam has contributed greatly to our club throughout his four years at Manchester United. His passion for helping young players to maximise their potential has played an important role in the success of our academy system.

“We take great pride in supporting and witnessing the development of our staff, Adam is a fine example of that, moving up from the Under-16s to the Under-18s, enjoying success and now being ready to seek a new challenge in the game.
“The whole of the academy thanks Adam for his service and wishes him the very best of luck for the future."

Lawrence was appointed as an Under-16 coach in January 2021 before being promoted to head of player development for the Under-13 to U16 age groups. He was subsequently appointed as U18 boss in the summer of 2023.
Lawrence oversaw a treble with the U18s last season, winning two trophies at the expense of rivals Man City, and he targeted winning the prestigious FA Youth Cup in this campaign.
However, the U18s were knocked out by Aston Villa at Villa Park on penalties in the Youth Cup semi-finals at the end of March. Villa went on to win the competition against Manchester City.
The U18s have finished second in the Premier League North this season. Lawrence has been praised for his contribution to the U18s and leaves United with the best wishes of the club.
It's understood talks are already under way to find a suitable replacement for Lawrence.

headline: Jadon Sancho handed fresh Man United exit path as surprise transfer reunion emerges
body: Jadon Sancho's future remains far from clear with doubts over his place at Chelsea and Manchester United almost certain not to reintegrate him back into their squad.

The 25-year-old is currently on loan at Stamford Bridge after joining Enzo Maresca's men late in the summer transfer window. After an impressive start to life in London, he has struggled to make an impact on the pitch.

In 40 games for the Blues, the England international has scored four goals and assisted 10, but he has managed just two goals and four assists in 2025. There is an obligation to make Sancho's loan move a permanent one in the summer for £25million, but there are serious doubts over that going through.

It's understood that Chelsea can escape the permanent transfers if they pay a £5m penalty to United. Earlier this week, The Mirror reported that they were ready to say goodbye to the former Borussia Dortmund winger in the summer.

A return to Germany has been touted for Sancho but it has now emerged that a different exit route could be presented to him. According to Turkish outlet Yeni Asir, Fenerbahce are attempting to sign Sancho to bolster their attack for next season.

The Yellow Canaries have conceded the Super Lig title this season to rivals Galatasaray and Jose Mourinho's side are expected to push for big names for next term. The report states that a deal worth £25m is being considered after Mourinho approved the deal.

United are claimed to now value Sancho at less than £20m with his reported £250,000-per-week wage demands expected to be a stumbling block in any deal. A move to Fenerbahce would see Sancho reunited with ex-United midfielder Fred, who joined Mourinho at the Ulker Stadium in 2023.

Turkey has welcomed some high-profile names in recent years with Victor Osimhen, Youssef En-Nesyri, Sofyan Amrabat, Davinson Sanchez, Milan Skriniar and Allan Saint-Maximin all making moves in recent years.

headline: Ruben Amorim warned Manchester United what was coming before accepting the job
body: Now or never was the message when Manchester United came knocking on Ruben Amorim's door last October.

After making the decision to sack Erik ten Hag less than 24 hours after a 2-1 defeat to West Ham United at the London Stadium, United earmarked Amorim as their top target to replace the Dutchman at Old Trafford.
United moved swiftly to get a deal in place, paying €10million (£8.3m) to trigger his Sporting Lisbon release clause.

Amorim had put Sporting back on the map, winning two Primeira Liga titles in three seasons after the club previously gone 19 years without being top dog in Portugal. Sporting's style of play was also attractive to United, with club bosses hopeful he would be able to revolutionise the Reds' fortunes with a new-look style.

However, Amorim was hesitant about making the move there and then, informing United that he wanted to wait until the summer to become United's next permanent head coach. He had already informed Sporting of his plan to leave the club at the end of the season.
United, though, were not willing to take no for an answer and Amorim had to make a life-changing decision there and then.
"The season started, we started very well, and then Manchester United came, they pay above the compensation clause and the president defends the club's interests," Amorim explained back in November.
"I never discussed anything with the president. For three days I said I wanted to stay until the end of the season, but then I was told it was not possible.
"It was now or never, or Manchester would go for another option. So, I had three days to make my mind up, to make a decision that changes radically my life."

On reflection, it is easy to understand why Amorim wanted to take charge at United ahead of the start of a new season, getting the opportunity to oversee a full pre-season and start afresh. Instead, he has overseen 14 defeats in his first 39 games in charge.
He said in February: "When you start a season it's completely different [how] you feel things, have pre-season and time to change things you feel are necessary in a team and a squad, that is clear.

"That was the choice so I don't want to talk about that. I had my reasons to ask for it and I have the most important reasons to accept the job. I knew it would be tough and a risk but it's Manchester United and you can't say no."
Of course, the fact Amorim has led United to the Europa League final cannot be ignored, and nor should it. He deserves credit for leading the club to their first European final since 2021.

However, if they are on the losing side against Tottenham Hotspur in Bilbao next week, it will count for nothing. Their Premier League campaign has been nothing short of embarrassing, with the defeat to West Ham leaving them 16th in the table with two games to go.

Defeats to Chelsea and Aston Villa either side of the final would see United end their Premier League campaign having lost half of their 38 matches. For a club of United's size, there is no escaping that.

Amorim inherited an expensively-assembled squad in November, still fresh from five new additions being added to it last summer, but its profile, as the last few months have highlighted countless times, is not wedded to Amorim's philosophy.
Only come the summer transfer window will Amorim get the chance to make just some of the necessary changes. It will be impossible for every change that needs to happen to take place in one window.

It is unfair to judge Amorim until he has had a meaningful opportunity to build his own squad, with only Patrick Dorgu and Ayden Heaven being signed since he was appointed, but he is not a position where he is immune from criticism.

He has won just 24 points from 25 Premier League games in charge, with ten of them being amassed against the three relegated clubs, highlighting just how poor United's league form has been in recent months.

It was clear from his initial hesitation about taking the job mid-season that he was conscious the timing wasn't right for him to come in and make an immediate impact, referencing the importance of pre-season. He will get the opportunity.

headline: Manchester United officially open voting for the 2024/2025 Player of the Year award
body: Manchester United have officially opened voting for their 2024/2025 Player of the Year award.
United fans have been encouraged to vote for the Sir Matt Busby Player of the Year award and the Goal of the Season award, which will be decided through polls on the club's website and app.
Bruno Fernandes won the award for a third time last season and he is the hot favourite to retain the prize. Only David de Gea and Cristiano Ronaldo have won the Sir Matt Busby award four times.
United have endured a miserable campaign and suffered a 17th Premier League defeat against West Ham on Sunday, but Fernandes' individual performances have remained strong.
Amad is also regarded as a front-runner for the Sir Matt Busby Player of the Year award.

There are other awards that will be handed out outside the fan-voted prizes, and members of United's dressing room will decide who receives the Players’ Player of the Year trophy.
Diogo Dalot enjoyed a consistent 2023/2024 and was a first-time winner of that award last term.

headline: LUCKHURST: United set Premier League target for next season
body: Manchester United are targeting a top six finish in the Premier League next season.

United plunged to 16th in the table with their 17th defeat in 36 league games against West Ham United at Old Trafford on Sunday. If they lose their remaining league fixtures at Chelsea and at home to Aston Villa then United will have lost half of their league matches this season.
Regardless of whether United win the Europa League and qualify for the Champions League, the club's power brokers believe a top six finish is an acceptable aim for next season.
The fifth-placed side in this season's Premier League will qualify for the Champions League, while sixth would secure Europa League qualification.
United are certain to record at least their joint-worst top flight finish since they were relegated in 1974 and they have lost their joint-most number of home games in a single season.
The eighth-place finish last term was United's worst since 1989-90 but they could slump to as low as 17th this term - one place above the relegation zone.

United head coach Ruben Amorim admitted he was "embarrassed" after the West Ham loss and that the club "needs to change a lot of things during the summer". He also suggested he would be sacked if United are in a similar state next season.

"For me, the biggest concern is that feeling it’s okay (to lose), we cannot change our position so much so it’s okay," he said. "That is the biggest problem in our club in this moment, because we are losing the feeling of we are a massive club and it’s the end of the world to lose a game at home. I think that is the biggest concern in our club.
"We need to be really strong in the summer and be brave. We will not have a next season like this if we start like this. If the feeling is still here we should give space to different persons."

headline: Rio Ferdinand shares health update after hospital stay forced Man United icon off-air
body: Manchester United legend Rio Ferdinand has opened up on his 'crazy' recent health scare that forced him to sit out of his TNT Sport punditry duties. The 46-year-old posted a concerning picture on social media in a hospital bed prior to Arsenal's Champions League semi-final and United's second-leg against Athletic Bilbao.

Despite his absence from the screen and the airwaves on co-commentary, he continued to post to social media as United booked their place in the Europa League final with a 4-1 win (7-1 on aggregate) over Bilbao.

He remained away from the broadcaster's Premier League coverage over the weekend with their cameras at St James' Park for a Champions League qualification showdown between Newcastle United and Chelsea.

Lynsey Hipgrave was accompanied by Joe Cole and Peter Crouch, while it remains to be seen whether he will be providing opinions for their coverage this weekend when they visit Goodison Park for Everton's farewell.
Speaking out for the first time, Ferdinand offered an update and a scary behind the scenes of the ordeal that left him hospitalised.
"My wife, the women in my family, will never know… man flu. That’s what it’s really about, man flu," he said, speaking on the Rio Ferdinand presents YouTube channel.
"I had a mad virus, bro. I thought lights were out at some point, I thought it was gonna happen.
"I thought I was minutes away from lights out, seriously.
"I was in my house, I was in my bed like this [pained expression] and I couldn’t even open my eyes.
"Then, the headache I had… I don’t get migraines or nothing else so I don’t know what they’re like.
"I thought my head was in a vice and my eyes were going to pop out."
He added: "Then, I was being sick, projectile vomiting in the toilet, I got back to bed and I was having vertigo.
"I was holding onto the sheets, I didn’t know where I was.
"It was crazy. I had to go to hospital and the doctor even said to me, 'Do you want an ambulance', so that’s when I knew.
"He went, ‘We’re going to get your brain scanned. I thought it was a virus or a flu or something so when he mentioned brain scan and the ambulance, the panic was nuts.
"I went to hospital and I was in there for a few days. I couldn’t even enjoy the hospital food.
"The soup and the ice cream normally does wonders."

headline: Manchester United on course for £22.4m loss that even Europa League glory cannot mask
body: 'Thursday' has been the clear message from Manchester United players in recent weeks as their Premier League form continued to tumble.

To their credit, the squad managed to turn up for the Europa League, and now just one match separates Ruben Amorim's side from an undeserving place in next season's Champions League, if Premier League form was anything to go by. Unfortunately, the United players did not have that excuse to hide behind on Sunday as they slipped to their 17th defeat of the season.

West Ham were in as rotten form as United, but Graham Potter managed to mastermind a victory over Amorim's team in a game which the hosts dominated on every statistic bar the one that matters. Just Chelsea stand in United's way now before that season-defining clash with Tottenham Hotspur in Bilbao.
A victory over Spurs and United could count the season's objective as being completed. Lose, and there is nowhere to hide.

Regardless of the result in the Basque Country, one matter that can't be hidden by Europa League glory is the substantial prize money loss that United will take from their league position. The exact figures for 2024/25 have not been confirmed yet, the Premier League often makes these figures public knowledge at the end of the campaign.

However, they are likely to be similar to last season, which saw each position earn £2.8m more than the position below them. After a disappointing campaign that saw United finish eighth, they bagged a respectable £36.4m.
If they finish 16th, which they occupy at the time of writing, they will manage to earn just £14m. This is a £22.4m loss from the season before.

Winning the Europa League would manage to bag United roughly an extra £10.95m but that still would not cover the shortfall for their low Premier League finish. The real bonus would come next season when they entered the Champions League with £15.7m earned just for qualifying for the competition.

However, that does not alter the stain that would be left on the finances this season. In a best case scenario, United could still finish as high as 13th which would bag them £22.4m based on last season's figures.
But for that to happen, they would need to beat Champions League chasing Chelsea with a heavily rotated squad and Aston Villa. So that seems unlikely.

More concerningly, if Spurs can pick up one extra point in their next two matches in comparison to United, the Reds will finish an embarassing 17th and will take home just £11m in prize money. Even the unlikely best case scenario is a measily sum compared to last season and forgetting the Premier League could cost United dearly in the transfer window.
Not only is the Europa League final imperative to instill some pride back into the club but it is also imperative for the finances of United.

headline: Man Utd: 12-goal PL striker ‘very happy’ to join Red Devils as £30m transfer ‘very close’
body: Liam Delap to Manchester United is “very close” despite interest from Chelsea, Nottingham Forest, and Newcastle United, according to reports.
Delap will leave Ipswich Town this summer following their relegation from the Premier League.
He is wanted by nearly every Premier League club, but United are believed to be leading the race for his signature.
The 22-year-old has a £30million release clause in his Ipswich contract, which is widely seen as a bargain — and explains why so many clubs are keen to sign him.
There is strong interest from Chelsea and Newcastle, while Nottingham Forest have also been touted as a potential destination, with the club on the verge of qualifying for Europe.

“What we’re hearing this afternoon is that Manchester United are in pole position to sign him. One source has even told us that he believes the deal is very close and that the player would be happy to move to Manchester United, even though United aren’t having a great season. He still feels they’re a big, big club.
